topic.title: Blocking users/hiding topics?
topic.body: Is it possible to block posts from specific users, or hide posts you're not interested in seeing? Looking for basic SPAM management.

topic.title: Mirroring web sites
topic.body:
In a comment thread someone posted a link to a page on an external web site. For one off pages you can mirror it in ZeroNet so others don't need to leave to the external web. I did it with `wget`:

     wget --no-parent --timestamping --convert-links --page-requisites \
              --no-directories --no-host-directories --span-hosts \
             --adjust-extension --no-check-certificate -e robots=off \
              -U 'Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.1.6) Gecko/20070804' \
              http://example.com/some/page/

The results end up in the current directory. I created a ZeroNet site for my own shares and put it in there.  To give you an idea of what you get, the site I tried it on is [here](/14DsvqL8GRPQ63D87eVB2sWsppJNs3r4Ew/mirror/visa-looks-senior-blockchain-developer/index.html).

(`wget` command shamelessly borrowed from how I've seen sites mirrored on Freenet)

2_17PhTjw3o2wPhxyKeM3Ss975eWZ1UMsjQC.body:
This is a problem unfortunately. If you use tor you make it more difficult for the fact that you are sharing the image to be tracked to you. It's still on your computer unencrypted though so if your computer is seized or searched you'll be in trouble. This could happen if you take it in to be repaired or cross an international border.

Ideally ZeroNet would encrypt the data files on disk. I hope that happens at some time. It'd be nice if image boards had their NSFW files set to 'optional' so users could choose to share them.

6_1NzjwWNcVjsX1ndBgkgC1EM5EUzMACGm8L.body:
I see what you are trying to do. Use a local IPFS instance if it's running otherwise fall back to the public IPFS proxies. It doesn't work for me - either the proxies are overloaded or possibly they download the entire file before starting the stream.

In the <video> element you have fallback code for the non-JavaScript case. You can remove this for ZeroNet since you must have JS.

Note that IPFS doesn't hide the streamers IP. This means both the receiver of the stream and the streamer can be identified. The ZeroNet user would need to be running Tor not just for Zeronet but for the browser as well. If they're using a local IPFS instance then they are identifiable until IPFS gets a Tor transport. This may not matter if you're streaming content you own.

> [o4zw5vmpoz5hz78z](#comment_107_1KTjPe9MxoYkcXj78GuZgCcj3R3f3Twh7r): You hit the Play Button, right?

Yes, I hit the play button. Possibly the IPFS proxies don't like Tor?
